ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND CONTRIBUTIONS
(Payment of rents and rates)


    1. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Labour, in order to help alleviate the present cost of living problem, if he will consider amending legislation to allow Singaporeans to use their Central Provident Fund contributions to settle their income tax, property tax, rents for Housing and Development Board flats and Public Utilities Board bills.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Central Provident Fund was set up to provide workers with savings for their old age or in the event of their being permanently disabled. The Government has already allowed members in the lower-income and middle-income group to utilise their CPF savings to purchase publicly-built flats. This is in accordance with the aim of providing for the workers' future and old age. To extend the use of CPF savings for the settling of income tax, property tax, rents for HDB and PUB bills, however, would not be consistent with the purpose for which the Fund was established.

    I therefore regret to inform the Member for Thomson that it is not proposed to amend the CPF legislation to allow the use of CPF contributions for the purposes indicated by him.

PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD
(Increase in revenue)


    2. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether the $18 million or 9% increase in income from electricity, gas and water in 1975, stated in the Economic Survey of Singapore. 1975, was due to the increase in consumption or to the increase in the rates of charges; and if he will ascertain from the Public Utilities Board the rates of charges for, and consumption of, electricity, gas and water in 1974 and in 1975.

Column: 516



    The Minister for National Development and Communications (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, the increase in revenue for the PUB for 1975 is estimated at $46 million, and not $18 million as mentioned by the Hon. Member. $18 million is the increase in the added value.

    To earn the extra $46 million, the PUB has spent $207.74 million in 1974 and $285.93 million in 1975 on the provision of infrastructure necessary to meet the increasing demand for power, water and gas. In the last three years, the PUB has spent $758.35 million on capital expenditure and had to borrow $410.34 million to finance development projects.

    Consumption of electricity has increased by 7.2 1% and gas by 9.47% in 1975. In both cases, there has been no increase in tariffs since February 1974, and the increase in revenue can be said to be due largely to the increase in consumption or sales.

    The tariff for electricity, for the information of Members, is based on a fuel oil price of $160 per tonne, and I would like Members to note that though the price of fuel oil increased to $182 per tonne in October 1975, that is, an increase of 13.75%, the tariff for electricity has not been raised. For the time being the PUB is able to absorb this increase in fuel oil price and other higher operating costs without passing it on to consumers, largely because of increased efficiency in the generation of electricity.

    Similarly for gas, because of greater efficiency, the PUB is also able to absorb increases in the price of naphtha without increasing the price of gas.

    Water tariffs, however, were revised upwards in October 1975, and this was to encourage economy in the use of water. It was also because the PUB had to spend $1 37.3 million on two major water supply projects, i.e, the Upper Peirce and Kranji/Pandan Schemes, to augment our water supply, storage and treatment capacities in order to cope with increasing consumption. Consumption for 1975 increased by 8.47%. It also costs more to

Column: 517

treat raw water which is as polluted as the kind we are getting from the Kranji/Pandan Dam. Incidentally, we are most fortunate in that we are able to complete these schemes before the recent drought. Otherwise. Members would have to miss their daily baths and would not look as clean as they do now. And if we had not completed these projects, there would have been water rationing or some other form of self-restraint would have been necessary.

    Water, as we know, is becoming increasingly expensive to tap as the PUB has to develop less economic sources of supply. Excessive use and wastage of water must be discouraged and I hope members of the public and Hon. Members too will keep on reminding themselves that, rain or shine, water is precious and must not be wasted.

TELEPHONE APPLICATIONS ON WAITING LIST
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for National Development and Communications if he will ascertain from the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore the number of applicants for telephones on the waiting list on 1st March, 1976; the average number annually of applicants for telephones and the number of telephones provided by the Authority since 1971; and what plans the Authority has to meet the increasing demand for telephones.

    The Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 1st March, 1976, there were a total number of 32,082 applicants waiting for

Column: 518

telephones. The number of applications for telephones and the number of telephones provided by the Authority since 1971 are as follows:

                      lines installed



1971    21,715            19,864

1972    27,098            20,257

1973    35,894            24,244

1974    40,876            25,240

    With increasing urbanisation and affluence, the growth in demand for telephone services had been phenomenal. In the 10 years since 1966, applications for telephones have almost increased five-fold from 11,000 to 51,000 today. The number of exchange lines installed has more than tripled from 64,000 to 210.000 today. Likewise, the number of people waiting for telephones has also increased. Actual growth is running at the rate of 20% per year while projected growth was only 1 5% per year.

    To keep pace with this rate of growth, the Authority is investing vast sums of money on equipment and cables as follows:

   Year              Million $

As development gathers momentum, the waiting list for telephones which is now 1 5.4% of total lines installed would be brought down progressively to just over 10% by the end of this year, and to 8% by the end of 1977. The Authority's long-term objective is to keep the waiting list to about 5%.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Sir, I was told that when the TAS introduced colour telephones, they levied an extra charge on those who applied for colour telephones. But this charge was later withdrawn. I want to know what is the justification for the extra charge in the first instance, and why was it withdrawn later.

Column: 519



    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, the reason for levying an extra charge in the early stages of the introduction of colour telephones was because there were a limited number of colour telephones available to meet the high demand for them. But since then the supply of colour telephones has been adequate, and it has therefore been decided to withdraw the extra charge.

    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Sir, I do believe it must have been bad planning on the part of the TAS because -Mr Speaker: Mr Baptist, are you asking a supplementary question?

    Mr Ivan Baptist: Yes, I am asking a supplementary question, Sir. The Minister of State must have been aware that there has been bad planning on the part of the TAS. According to his figures. actual growth was 20% per year and the TAS projected only 1 5%, that is, about 25% off the mark.

    Mr Speaker: What is your supplementary question?

    Mr Ivan Baptist: I am just wondering whether or not the Hon. Minister of State would take steps to ensure that this error will not occur in the projection for the next five years. From the figures he has given, things are getting from bad to worse.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: As has been given in my answer earlier. Sir, this waiting list will be progressively reduced from the current rate of 15.4% to 8% by the end of 1977. It is not possible to provide a system or service where there would be a 100% fulfilment, or a "zero" waiting time. There must be some amount of waiting time. The long-term objective, as I have mentioned earlier, is to keep this waiting list down to the minimum and I can assure the Member that every effort is being made to achieve this.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, arising from the Minister of State's answer to my question in respect of the charge for colour telephones, may I know whether it was because the TAS had to pay more for the colour telephones, or whether they charged it simply because the people demanded it. What is the difference in

Column: 520

cost between the colour telephone and the conventional black sets?

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, I do not think there is any difference between the cost of a colour telephone and an ordinary black telephone. I do not know what the actual reasons were when the colour set was introduced, but I believe the extra charge was to deter the high demand at that time.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, sometimes the statement of accounts from the TAS is confusing, and sometimes it takes three or four months to arrive.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Govindaswamy, are you asking a supplementary question?

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Yes, Sir. Will the Minister take steps to ensure that the statement of accounts will be sent regularly every month?

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: It is assured. Sir.

MOTOR-CYCLE AND SCOOTER RIDERS
(Dangerous driving)


    4. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for National Development and Communications if it is feasible to confine motor-cycle and scooter riders, especially provisional licence holders, to the inner lanes of carriageways and to limit their speed so as to prevent them from weaving their way through the traffic and endangering other road users.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Sir, I wish to inform the Member that existing traffic regulations already disallow dangerous weaving through the traffic by motor-cycle and scooter riders. If caught by the traffic enforcement officers, they will be booked for inconsiderate or even dangerous driving. Motor-cycle and scooter riders should move with the general traffic and observe the speed limits imposed for the stretch of road they are travelling on.

    Admittedly, it is desirable to segregate and to have separate lanes for the different types of vehicles. However, in Singapore the

Column: 521

shortage of land and limited road space have made it difficult, if not impossible, for this to be so, and serious problems especially at road junctions will be encountered if segregation of vehicles is practised. A good example is our bus lane which is not without its problems. However, in this case the benefits far outweigh the disadvantages. Even then, bus lanes have been introduced only to certain main roads.

    It is a requirement of law, as well as simple courtesy, that slow-moving vehicles should move on the left lane to allow faster vehicles to proceed on the lane to the right without hindrance. The left lane is thus meant for use by slow-moving vehicles such as buses and goods vehicles. It would, hence, be most unfair to confine motor-cycles and scooters to the left lane as they would have to move at unrealistic slow speeds among the heavy vehicles and this is dangerous for them. The existing situation allows flexibility and is desirable since most of our carriageways have only two lanes. If a motorcycle or a scooter rider is moving slowly, he should keep to the left lane. If he moves faster and wants to by-pass a slow-moving vehicle in front, he can do so in the outer lane to the right. However, at all times he should observe all traffic regulations, and traffic enforcement officers are keeping a sharp watch to ensure that this is being done.

    Efforts will continue to be made to educate motor-cycle and scooter riders on the rules and regulations regarding road use. The requirement as from 1st January, 1974 that provisional driving licence holders should pass their Highway Code test before being allowed to drive or ride on the road has also helped to reduce traffic offences and accidents caused by motor-cycle and scooter riders.

    Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, I am just wondering if the Hon. Minister of State is aware that PDL holders are, in actual fact, endangering the lives of other road users. In addition, is the Minister aware that many PDL holders continue to hold PDLs and nothing else year after year? They are unable to pass the road

Column: 522

test, and they are still being issued with PDLs. This system is making the traffic situation almost impossible. What action is he proposing to take on PDL holders who continue to renew their PDLs year after year?

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: In answer to the question raised by the Member for Potong Pasir, action is being taken to see that this is regularised. As I have said, as far as the learner drivers are concerned, they should observe the rules and regulations governing road use. It is very much a question of public courtesy and mutual respect for other road users. No amount of enforcement of rules that we are able to introduce will make our roads any safer without the cooperation of the drivers themselves.

    Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, I am not talking about PDL motor car drivers. I am talking about PDL scooterists and motor cyclists. Where they are concerned, they can ride the scooter without a tutor sitting by their side to guide them where proper driving is concerned, which is impossible because he would be sitting on the road) I am talking about motorcyclists and scooterists and I am wondering whether the Minister is aware of the fact that they do not even go for road tests. They are quite satisfied with displaying the L-plate, the red letter "L" on a white background. In addition, they are the ones mainly responsible for most accidents on the roads.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, in my earlier answer I did mention that they now have to go for a Highway Code test, which was not required in the past.

    Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, I do not believe that a Highway Code test will actually give them the practical experience on the road. A Highway Code test is merely a written examination as well as pushing little toy cars and motor-cycles around.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: I would welcome constructive suggestions from the Member on how to overcome this problem.

    Mr Ivan Baptist: Most certainly.

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I would like to make reference to the Housing Board's policy in regard to restrictions imposed on visitors using their car parks when calling on friends living in Housing Board flats.

    On the one hand, the Government proudly announces that public housing provides accommodation for more than 40% of Singapore's population and has urged the people to develop a greater sense of neighbourliness not only in their own estates but also with those in the estates around them. On the other hand, the Housing Board appears to be determined to stultify every attempt at neighbourliness by imposing petty restrictions, such as the closing of car parks at 10 p.m, and even at 7 p.m, in some estates. This makes it difficult for residents to receive friends for any length of time in the evenings.

    Sir, it is difficult to comprehend the rationale behind this restriction if the Housing Board is really sincere in their attempt to encourage neighbourliness and cohesiveness among the residents in the housing estates. I believe that in some housing estates visitors are allowed to use the Housing Board car parks until 11 p.m. If this is so, why is it not allowed in other HDB housing estates? This extension will at least allow friends to meet for a few hours after work. In fact, the Housing Board should permit visitors to utilise their car parks until

Column: 524

midnight. I am sure that there can be no administrative problem in keeping the Housing Board car parks open till midnight.

    Sir, I have suggested extension of use of the car parks until midnight because as Singapore becomes urbanised so also must the life-styles of Singaporeans change. Thirty years ago when we were less urbanised and less industrialised, life went on at a slower pace and most people retire early to bed. Living in flats and apartments and the tempo of life today, including television, have all contributed to encouraging or even compelling Singaporeans to sleep late. Because of longer working hours and transport problems, social calls to friends are usually possible only after 8 p.m., and if visitors to residents in Housing Board estates have to clear their cars out by 10 p.m, it leaves very little time indeed for them to socialise. We have not got a wonderful public transport system to encourage them to travel in public transport. They therefore have to travel in their own motor cars.

    In addition, Sir, young couples living in Housing Board flats have been encouraged to invite their parents to visit them frequently and to help look after their children when they are out. But the Housing Board's car park rules make this practically impossible if grandparents who make the visit by car have to clear out by 10p.m. This 10 p.m-deadline has a very unsettling and unnerving effect on visitors because if, by any chance, they are delayed by a few minutes they may find their cars locked in or parking posts chained at the whims of the Housing Board officials. Moreover, they will also be subject to a heavy penalty.

    Sir, it would appear that the officials of the Housing Board are insensitive to the requirements and wishes of the residents of the flats, although they have been administering the flats for more than a decade. May I, therefore, request the Housing Board to take a closer look at its rules and regulations and consult the residents through the residents' association or other organisations and work out more pragmatic schemes not only in respect of car

Column: 525

parking but also in other matters. This will be a more democratic approach instead of introducing arbitrary rules.

    One such arbitrary rule which puzzles me is why residents who are allotted car park lots are not allowed to park their cars for a few hours in an adjoining car park when vacant, if they have a reason to do so. Apparently the Housing Board's rule, for reasons best known to themselves, is that "you shall park your car in your given lot and nowhere else", even if there are vacant lots in adjoining car parks.

    It seems to me, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the Housing Board is determined to forge a regimented society, a society that will obediently abide by their many arbitrary rules and regulations, and may not seek redress. This attitude of the Housing Board appears to stem from their monopoly in public housing. As the biggest landlord, they appear to be succumbing to the thirst for power by dictating the rules instead of arriving at mutually acceptable rules and regulations that will equally provide discipline necessary for the efficient management of housing estates.

    I would also like to seek clarification from the Minister as to the reason for abolishing the half-hour parking in Housing Board estates at a rate of 20 cents and substituting it with a minimum fee of 40 cents in the hour. This new rate means that anybody who parks his car there even for a short while has to pay the minimum rate of 40 cents for a full hour. This appears to be an arbitrary decision without any justification whatsoever. It excites suspicion that the Housing Board merely wishes to increase its revenue. In most cases people stop by at these car parks for a few minutes only to speak to their friends or to have a quick meal at the restaurant, or to make some purchases at the supermarket there. So although they may be there only for 15 to 20 minutes, they now have to pay the minimum fee of 40 cents. In the past it was 20 cents for half an hour, and it is difficult to understand the reason for the increase.

Column: 526



    If the Housing Board is really honest in its declared intention to encourage greater intermingling and interaction among the residents of the different Housing Board estates, these arbitrary rules do pose a serious problem because in the not too distant future more than half of Singapore's population will be living in Housing Board flats. And if the Housing Board continues to build artificial barriers to prevent the free interflow of residents in those estates

    The Chairman: Mr Ho, you have taken more than 10 minutes.

    Mr Ho See Beng: I am closing it, Sir, I was saying that the residents will soon be cut off from their friends and neighbours and remain isolated, living in solitude within the four walls of their little flat. I can only express the hope that this increase in parking fee from 20 cents to 40 cents is the result of an honest mistake on the part of the Board's officials and not a perverse desire to isolate the residents.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, much has already been said about the Housing and Development Board and my first thought was, perhaps, sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof.

    However, there is one point I would like especially to make and that relates to the Tanjong Rhu housing estate, and I hope this will not be considered as a particular or special pleading. The Tanjong Rhu housing estate was constructed in 1962, quite soon after the HDB replaced the old Singapore Improvement Trust. The flats raised at Tanjong Rhu were, in fact, sometimes described as "emergency flats" aimed at making up for the backlog of people that had to be housed urgently at that time and at resettling displaced families. Quite a lot of fire victims from Geylang and Crawford were moved there.

    Since that time the quality of HDB accommodation has improved tremendously. When I compare the Tanjong Rhu estate with the new estates like Marine Parade in the next door constituency - in fact, with your constituency of Joo Chiat, Mr Speaker, or

Column: 527

with Ulu Pandan, or Bedok and soon - I am struck by the comparative shortage of amenities that we have in Tanjong Rhu. Tanjong Rhu estate may well be unique in the spartan considerations that went into its construction. On this basis I think consideration of priority ought to be given to this estate for whatever improvement that may be planned, and I think Tanjong Rhu estate deserves a special look in this direction.

    For example, it could have a community hall of which some other estates have several. Could we have this early? Could the lay-out and appearance of the market/hawker centre be improved, and its potential for service to the community extended? Could additional car parking facilities be made available? Many of the tenants are living in extremely crowded circu mstances; perhaps if the Minister makes an examination of Tanjong Rhu estate, he might find the highest number of people with very large families living there. Could consideration be given as early as possible to rehousing those people in such circumstances?

    I am very reluctant to want to receive special consideration, but I think the history and circumstances of Tanjong Rhu estate may well warrant some special attention.

    In regard to the other points that have been raised, especially relations between Housing Board officials and the people living in housing estates -

    Mr Ho See Beng: You have a swimming pool there.

    Mr Conceicao: I will come to the swimming pool a little later.

    I think every effort should be made to emphasise a spirit of cooperation and understanding of the problems of one side with the other. With the kind of idea that many people have about the Housing Board, it would be a pity indeed if it is thought of as a cow that gives good milk and then kicks the bucket over.

    With regard to this red herring that has been raised, the swimming pool is not only

Column: 528

meant for the people in my constituency but for everybody around there within an adequate radius - Mountbatten and J00 Chiat - and if the Member for Bras Basah wants to have a swim he is entitled to come over for a swim too.

    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang): Let me first answer the question raised by the Member for Telok Blangah. Together with a few other Members, he has raised some observations on the need to improve the standard of workmanship in public housing. As a result of their observations, the Ministry of National Development issued a press statement on 21st February, 1976, explaining in great detail the causes of the poor workmanship. I have a copy of the statement here which could be handed to the Member at a later stage.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): I have read it.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang: I am glad the Member has read it. The second point which he raised is whether the Board could refund the proportion of the unused fee for a season parking licence taken by one of his constituents. The Board cannot make such a refund to a resident who has already been allocated a parking lot. This means that he had been successful in balloting for a parking lot and had thus deprived another person of that particular parking lot. The same principle applies to a person who pays road tax to the Registry of Vehicles. If he decides to sell his car, he cannot ask the ROV for a refund of tax for the unexpired period. It is between him and the purchaser. The same principle applies to a TV licence. But, to satisfy the Member, should the car owner deregister his car immediately, that means, he really takes it off the road, then the Board would allow a refund of the unexpired season parking charges, to keep in line with Government's policy of discouraging car ownership. In respect of this particular car. I have checked with the ROV this morning and I found that it has not been deregistered.

Column: 529



    Another point raised by the Member is about the Housing Board being a stickler of principles in regard to the processing of plans for community centres. Let me reply by simply saying that whenever the People's Association decides to build a community centre in a Housing Board estate it forwards its plan to the Ministry of Finance for endorsement. In the meantime the Housing Board goes ahead with the processing of the plan. At this point it is the normal practice for the Housing Board to request the People's Association to pay for the piece of land as soon as it can. In fact, a six-month extension period is normally given. It should be borne in mind that whatever the Housing Board charges the People's Association, the price of the land is kept extremely low.

    The next question raised was in regard to helping the tenants and the contractors. As he has correctly pointed out, contractors are licensed by the Housing Board. But if complaints about them are substantiated, then the Housing Board can do something; perhaps their licence could be terminated and their deposit of $5,000 forfeited. They can also be black-listed and debarred from doing any renovation work in any Housing Board estate. I think I have covered all the queries raised by the Member for Telok Blangah.
